important_phrase: Scattered rains improved soil moisture levels to segments of the District, in particular Alabama and parts of Georgia
Labor markets remained weak
Several employers noted that highly skilled workers are being kept on payrolls as long as possible because of concerns about being able to hire them back later
Most District banking contacts reported that credit conditions remained tight
Inter-modal shipments were lower than year-earlier levels
Overall, housing inventories increased and home prices declined across the District
District retailers reported that weakness persisted during June and early July with sales performing below expectations
Business contacts in the First District generally report slowing economic activity
Almost all contacted manufacturers voice concerns about elevated materials, transportation, and energy costs
Residential real estate markets in New England continue to show slower sales in 2008 than in 2007
Capital spending is also mixed
Flooding compounded the problems of already slower-than-normal corn and soybean planting in the District
Manufacturing activity weakened slightly
The rate of growth in steel prices flattened, but prices remained elevated
Consumer loan demand continued to decline as lenders further tightened standards
Manufacturing activity in the District weakened slightly from the previous reporting period
The pace of construction slowed slightly from the previous reporting period
Federal tax rebates and increased discounting boosted retail sales, but spending on automobiles slowed
Oil, gas, and coal production has been steady to increasing during the past six weeks
Energy production was stable to increasing
Core deposits were stable to increasing, with several community bankers characterizing deposit increases as a "flight to safety" from equity markets and large banks
Capacity utilization was at, or slightly below normal levels
Home builders reported little change in market conditions--flat to declining sales and a slowdown in traffic
Our respondents were very cautious in their outlook for the third quarter, with the expectation of some slowdown in sales
Drilling companies are adding jobs but report having difficulty finding workers with the skills they need
Most contacts reported increased concern about price pressures and uncertainty about the national outlook
The labor market remained relatively tight, but most respondents reported flat to only slightly increasing payrolls
Commercial lending activity remains fairly solid
Demand in the food products industry has been moderate with contacts reporting some recent improvement in sales growth
Homebuilders said that traffic and sales weakened fairly significantly in June, following weak but steady demand earlier in the spring
Retail sales were mixed--with discount stores reporting stronger sales and other retailers reporting flat to slightly declining sales
Farmland price appreciation also slowed from its record pace
Commercial real estate saw some improvement, but the outlook was modest
Price pressures continued to build since the last survey period, but wages remained steady with little upward pressure
Bankers reported tighter credit standards and slightly weaker loan demand than in the previous survey
Manufacturing activity declined in June and early July
The residential real estate market in the District was weak, but has stabilized, while commercial real estate activity improved modestly, but with a weaker outlook
Some business contacts reported that low consumer confidence and high gasoline prices have softened sales
Agricultural conditions were mixed
Wges increased moderately, while significant price increases were noted for fuel and energy; lumber prices were lower
Wge increases were moderate
) indicated increased activity in the Dakotas and slightly decreased activity in Minnesota
Residential construction remained slow
Tourism activity increased
Most Districts reported concerns about higher input costs
Commercial real estate activity also slowed or remained sluggish in a majority of Districts, although a few Districts noted slight improvement
All reporting Districts characterized overall price pressures as elevated or increasing
St Louis reported slightly positive overall loan demand
Manufacturing activity declined or remained weak in most Districts, although Cleveland, St Louis, and San Francisco reported stable or slightly increasing activity
Commercial real estate activity weakened or remained sluggish in a majority of Districts, although Cleveland, Minneapolis, and Kansas City noted some improvement
Atlanta also noted increased hotel cancellations and shorter trip durations, although convention business remained strong
Manufacturers report that business activity has been steady to slower since the last report, and that increases in both input costs and selling prices remain widespread
Finally, bankers indicate increased delinquencies on consumer loans and residential mortgages but little change in delinquency rates for commercial mortgages and commercial and industrial loans
A major New York City employment agency, specializing in office jobs, reports that hiring activity slowed further in June and early July
Vaancy rates were little changed at high levels in northern and central New Jersey, edged up in Fairfield County, but edged down in Wstchester
Average ticket prices are running slightly lower than a year ago
Bank lending has been increasing slowly in recent weeks
Most of the firms reporting on employment costs in July indicated that wage increases remained moderate
Most of the banks surveyed reported slow but steady growth in commercial and industrial lending, an easing in expansion of consumer credit, and very slight increases in real estate lending
One firm cited "general uncertainty about demand" and another said "concern about tax increases are a drag on business expansion
Rents have been steady
Although sales of some foreign small cars were rising, total sales of light vehicles were well below the level of a year ago
In North Carolina, showers helped alleviate drought concerns in the Central Piedmont and Central Coastal regions of the state, while precipitation in South Carolina improved peanut growing conditions
Additionally, residential real estate sales were slower in most markets, as was residential lending activity
Fifth District temporary employment agents generally reported weaker demand for workers since our last report
On the commercial lending front, activity was generally stable
Import volumes remained steady in recent weeks, although several officials noted slight slowdowns from Northern Europe
Residential real estate agents across the District reported generally slower home sales in June and early July as uncertain economic conditions kept some prospective buyers sitting on the sidelines
Retail prices grew a bit more slowly since our last report, although several contacts noted that ongoing supplier price increases would be passed through to customers
Demand remained robust for agricultural items and natural resources
Retail sales were sluggish, and demand growth slowed further for service providers
Price inflation was moderate for most items, although increases in food and energy prices continued to put upward pressure on overall inflation
Reports on commercial and industrial lending were mixed, with some contacts reporting a noticeable pullback in demand and others reporting steady conditions, suggesting slight easing overall
District manufacturing activity was mixed across sectors but appeared to expand on net during the survey period of June through early July

Demand for new and existing homes remained exceptionally weak, fueling further price declines, especially in parts of California, Arizona, and Nevada that also have seen sharp increases in home foreclosures
Demand growth for service providers slowed further
The development of the District's major crops remains behind its 5-year averages
Retail sales reports were mixed
Total loans outstanding at a sample of small and mid-sized District banks increased , percent from early April to mid-June
Contacts reported concerns about the ensuing effects on employment from ongoing consolidations in the brewing industry in the St Louis area
A top regional contracting contact in Memphis was optimistic concerning projects for the remainder of 2008, but a contact in Evansville, Indiana, reported that industrial construction has slowed
